fields.english_script: EN script

fields.english_objective: Assess the general understanding of cavity development in young children
fields.english_title: Vertical Transmission- can germs be passed along
fields.english_script: Now I am going to ask you a general question about children’s cavities.  Would you say the following statement is true, false or you are not sure- A mother can pass cavity-causing germs to their child.

fields.english_objective: Dental caries is a disease that is transmitted from mother to child.  Utensils may be a way to transfer bacteria from mother to child.
fields.english_script: When you are feeding your child, how often do you share utensils with them?

fields.english_objective: Learn the importance of limiting sugary foods
fields.english_title: Cutting back on sugar intake- How difficult is it to cut back on the number of sweets your child eats?
fields.english_script_instructions:
Water is the best drink for children to have if they are thirsty between meals. Juice should be limited to meals and set snack times.  Sweetened foods and beverages should be offered with meals.  Sweets should not be offered as rewards.  Sweets should be planned so they are eaten all at once and not throughout the day.  HARMFUL TO TEETH are sweets that are sucked, stick to teeth, or dissolve slowly.  Less sticky treats include:  nuts, popcorn, pumpkin or sunflower seeds, and fresh juicy fruit such as apples, berries and melon.

After eating sweet foods children should: drink water; eat cheese or milk; munch raw carrots, celery, apples or other wet-crisp, vegetables and fruits; best yet- brush their teeth with fluoride toothpaste.
fields.english_script: We are going to talk a little bit more about what your child likes to eat.  How difficult is it to cut back on the number of sweets your child eats and drinks?

fields.english_objective: Dental caries is a disease that is transmitted from mother to child.  Pacifiers may be a way to transfer bacteria from mother to child.
fields.english_script: Pacifiers can be soothing for children.  Does your child use a pacifier?  If it falls, how do you usually clean it?  Sometimes if mothers are in a rush they might clean it by putting it in their mouth. How often would you say you clean your child's pacifier by putting it in your mouth?

fields.english_objective: Learn that allowing a child to drink slowly, frequently and over long periods of time out of a bottle or sippy cup increases their risk for developing Early Childhood Caries.
fields.english_title: Bottle & Sippy Cup use during the day
fields.english_script_instructions:
Parents may be anxious about taking the bottle away from their child if it helps them relax, sleep better, or stop crying.  Provide some suggestions on how to start a nighttime routine that does not include the bottle such as: sing or play music; hold or rock the baby; rub or pat the baby’s head or back; read or tell a story.  

If the baby already sleeps with a bottle, be sure he/she is fed before being put to bed.  Wipe teeth with a damp cloth after feeding. There are several techniques to try to wean a child from the bottle.  (1) Try giving a child the bottle in the living room with the family, then brush their teeth, go to their room and read, sing, and rock. This makes the baby not dependent on the bottle as a sleep crutch. (2) Try gradually diluting the liquid in the bottle with water until there is only water in the bottle.  
(3) Also try to take it away slowly such as half an ounce out a day until it is gone then it can be taken away completely. 
(4) If the child is having multiple bottles per day, take one bottle away at a time. 
(5) If the baby is already a toddler and goes to bed with a bottle, explain that he/she is too big to have a bottle in bed anymore.

Children may have a hard time learning to sleep without it but eventually they will get the hang of it.  This may not be an easy or fast transition.  It may take days, weeks or even longer for the baby to give up the bottle in bed, but the mother needs to remain consistent in her actions.
fields.english_script: Now let’s talk about what your child usually drinks out of.  Tell me about what type of cup they usually use? (look at pictures of cups and bottles) A bottle? A sippy cup? A regular cup?  If they use bottles or sippy cups, how often do they sip a sugared drink such as juice or soda from one throughout the day?

fields.english_objective: Learn about what early childhood caries  is and how it may impact their child.
fields.english_title: Clinical history- how much of a problem with tooth decay
fields.english_script_instructions: ECC happens when foods or liquids that contain sugar (such as milk, formula, soda, juice, blended foods) are left in a baby’s mouth frequently or for long periods of time and/or a baby’s teeth are not brushed regularly.  ECC can start as soon as a child’s teeth come in.  ECC can change how the child looks.  This may affect how a child feels about him/herself.  ECC may cause developmental speech problems.
fields.english_script: Now we are going to talk about your child’s risk for early childhood caries and tooth decay.  In general, how much of a problem would you say your child has had with tooth decay?

fields.english_objective: Learn the importance of routinely bringing all children to the dentist.
fields.english_script: Has your child had a cavity in the last 12 months?

fields.english_objective: Learn about the importance of fluoride in protecting teeth from decay and how much is appropriate for their child.
fields.english_script_instructions: Tap water is the most common source of fluoride.  New York City community water is fluoridated.  If your child only drinks bottled water they may not be receiving the benefits of community fluoride.  Some parents purchase bottled water for their children to drink instead of tap water. Most bottled waters lack fluoride, but fluoridated bottled water is now available.  Many New Yorkers come from places where it's unsafe to drink tap water. Or they're simply getting out of the tap water habit.  New York City tap water is fluoridated
fields.english_script: What type of water does your child drink most often?  Bottled, tap or both?

fields.english_objective: Learn about the importance of fluoride in protecting teeth from decay and how much is appropriate for their child.
fields.english_script: Does your child ever use a fluoride rinse (show mother pictures of fluoride rinses).  If so, how many times a day?

fields.english_objective: Learn about the importance of fluoride in protecting teeth from decay and how much is appropriate for their child.
fields.english_script: Does your child ever use prescription toothpaste?  If so, how many times a day?

fields.english_title: Tooth brushing- Someone other than primary parent brushing child’s teeth
fields.english_script_instructions:
Parents should make tooth brushing appear as a fun activity; if the parent is enthusiastic about the activity, the children will be enthusiastic.Kids like routine so parents should also set regular tooth brushing times and stick to them.  If possible, kids picking out their own toothbrush may help get them excited about it. 

For infants without teeth, gums should be wiped with a clean, damp cloth.  When teeth start to come in, parents should switch to a small soft toothbrush.  For children under 2- only a thin film of toothpaste should be used. For children over 2- a pea-sized amount of toothpaste should be used. Parents should supervise brushing until their child is 6-7 years old (Being able to tie own shoes and coloring within the lines are good markers.)  Most young children can hold and move a brush in their mouths BUT, they usually do a very poor job of brushing their teeth.  Brushing should be a family routine where the parent allows child to brush their teeth on their own with the parent “checking how they did” by brushing their teeth an additional time.
fields.english_script: Speaking of who brushes your child’s teeth most often, is there someone other than yourself who helps brush your child’s teeth?

fields.english_objective: Learn that certain teething remedies may increase caries risk.
fields.english_script: If your child uses pacifiers, they may be especially soothing when they are teething or uncomfortable.  Do you ever put honey, sugar or syrup on your child’s gums or pacifier?  If so, how often?

fields.english_objective: Learn about the oral hygiene habits of the mother’s community
fields.english_title: Tooth brushing- Most mothers I know brush their children’s teeth daily
fields.english_script: Would you say you agree, disagree or are unsure about the following statement? Most mothers you know brush their child’s teeth every day.

fields.english_objective: Learn how to conduct a lift the lip exam on their child
fields.english_script: There is a simple way to check for early signs of early childhood caries by lifting your child’s lip and looking closely at their teeth.  The exam takes only a few seconds and can easily become a part of your child’s brushing routine.  Start by gently lifting your child’s upper lip and cheek. Children’s teeth should all be the same color.  Do you see any white spots on your child's upper four front teeth?

fields.english_objective: Learn the importance of limiting sugary foods
fields.english_title: Cutting back on sugar intake- Most mothers I know don’t let their children have sugary drinks or snacks between meals
fields.english_script_instructions:
Water is the best drink for children to have if they are thirsty between meals. Juice should be limited to meals and set snack times.  Sweetened foods and beverages should be offered with meals.  Sweets should not be offered as rewards.  Sweets should be planned so they are eaten all at once and not throughout the day.  HARMFUL TO TEETH are sweets that are sucked, stick to teeth, or dissolve slowly.  Less sticky treats include:  nuts, popcorn, pumpkin or sunflower seeds, and fresh juicy fruit such as apples, berries and melon.

After eating sweet foods children should: drink water; eat cheese or milk; munch raw carrots, celery, apples or other wet-crisp, vegetables and fruits; best yet- brush their teeth with fluoride toothpaste.
fields.english_script: Sometimes friends and family offer helpful advice on how to get children to eat healthy.  Would you say that you agree, disagree or are unsure that most mothers you know don’t let their children have high sugar drinks and snacks between meals?

fields.english_objective: Learn about what early childhood caries (ECC) is and how it may impact their child.
fields.english_title: Thoughts and feelings- cavities can be prevented
fields.english_script_instructions: Parents forget or are misinformed about caring for their children’s baby teeth because they will fall out and are replaced with adult teeth.  The baby teeth help the adult teeth to come in correctly and are very important for a child to be able to eat, speak, and feel good about him/herself.
fields.english_script: Would you say the following statement is true, false or you are unsure?  Cavities can be prevented.

fields.english_objective: Learn about the importance of fluoride in protecting teeth from decay and how much is appropriate for their child.
fields.english_script: Would you say the following statement is true, false or you are unsure?  Products containing fluoride help to strengthen teeth and prevent cavities.

fields.english_objective: Learn age appropriate methods for cleaning children’s teeth
fields.english_title: Tooth brushing- Who most routinely brushes the child’s teeth?
fields.english_script_instructions:
Parents should make tooth brushing appear as a fun activity; if the parent is enthusiastic about the activity, the children will be enthusiastic. Parents should make brushing seem like a fun thing to do rather than a chore. Kids like routine so parents should also set regular tooth brushing times and stick to them.  If possible, kids picking out their own toothbrush may help get them excited about it. 

For infants without teeth, gums should be wiped with a clean, damp cloth.  When teeth start to come in, parents should switch to a small soft toothbrush.  For children under 2- only a thin film of toothpaste should be used. For children over 2- a pea-sized amount of toothpaste should be used. Brushing should be a family routine where the parent allows child to brush their teeth on their own with the parent “checking how they did” by brushing their teeth an additional time.
fields.english_script: So you said child’s teeth are brushed x times a day.  Do they like to brush their teeth themselves?  Who most routinely brushes your child’s teeth? You, your child, both of you together, or neither of you.

fields.english_objective: Learn the importance of the parent’s oral health
fields.english_script_instructions: When selecting a toothbrush parents should be sure to pick one with soft or ultra-soft bristles.  Ideally, one should spend at least 2 minutes brushing teeth.  Routinely flossing and visiting the dentist is just as important as brushing.  Dental floss helps to clean the areas that your toothbrush can not reach.  In adults, it is very common for these spaces to get cavities.
fields.english_script: Now we are going to spend a little time talking about your own dental habits.  One of the best ways for a parent to help keep their child’s mouth healthy is by keeping their own mouths healthy.  It is also very common to have a history of cavities.  Have you ever had an abscessed tooth?

fields.english_objective: Learn the importance of the parent’s oral health
fields.english_title: Parental Oral Health- history of tooth decay
fields.spanish_script: En general, ¿qué tan problemáticas han sido las caries para usted y sus otros hijos?
fields.english_script: In general, how much of a problem have you or your other children had with tooth decay?

fields.english_objective: Learn the importance of routinely bringing all children to the dentist.
fields.english_script_instructions:
A child’s first dental visit should be scheduled with a Pediatric Dentist shortly after their first tooth comes in and no later than their first birthday.  The dentist may recommend that the child come back at different times for checkups- sometimes as soon as 3 months and sometimes as long as 1 year.

It is important not to frighten or negatively influence a child about going to the dentist. Don’t threaten child (even as a joke) about taking a tooth out or getting “a shot”, keep siblings from this as well.    Be honest with a child about the dental appointment.  Take some time to explain what will happen beforehand.  Depending on the dentist, parents may accompany the child during treatment.  Other times they may be asked to wait by the door or outside in the waiting room.  It is important that the parent have any questions answered by the dental staff and is comfortable with the treatment plan.  The parent should also inform dental staff of any medical information or any specific dental concern prior to the visit so that both you and the dental staff are prepared that day.
fields.english_script: Next we are going to talk about visiting the dentist.  Has your child had a routine dental checkup in the last 12 months?

fields.english_objective: Learn about the importance of fluoride in protecting teeth from decay and how much is appropriate for their child.
fields.english_script_instructions: Parents may be concerned with using toothpaste with fluoride.  Assure them that when used correctly, fluoride toothpaste is safe and one of the best ways to prevent cavities in their children.  Products containing fluoride should be stored out of the reach of young children.  Children should be encouraged to spit out the toothpaste.  Use only a small amount (smear to pea-sized) when assisting a child in brushing.  Ingesting too much fluoride can make a child ill and/or cause the permanent teeth to come in with white spots/discolorations on them.  This condition is called enamel fluorosis.  Parents should dispense toothpaste to prevent their young children from swallowing too much. Use a smear of fluoridated toothpaste for children under 2 and a pea-sized amount of toothpaste for children 2-5 years old.  At your child’s regular check-ups, the dentist may recommend that a child receive a professional fluoride application.
fields.english_script: Let’s talk about the type of toothpaste that your child uses.  It seems like there are so many brands of toothpaste to choose from (show mother pictures of toothpaste). Is there one type of toothpaste that your child likes to use?  Some toothpaste contains a mineral called fluoride, have you heard of that before?  Do you know if the toothpaste your child uses is a fluoride or non-fluoride toothpaste?

fields.english_objective: Dental caries is a disease that is transmitted from mother to child.  Pre chewing food may be a way to transfer bacteria from mother to child.
fields.english_script: When children are still too young to eat solid food, parents may pre-chew the food to make it easier for them to eat.  How often do you pre-chew your child's food?

fields.english_objective: Learn about what early childhood caries (ECC) is and how it may impact their child.
fields.english_title: Thoughts and feelings-  parents confidence in reducing tooth decay
fields.english_script_instructions: Parents and caregivers play a very important role in finding and preventing ECC by: not letting child sleep with a baby bottle; switching to an infant cup by 12 months of age;  assisting child in tooth-brushing and ‘lifting the lip’ to check for ‘white spots’; regular dental visits; and a healthy diet with limited snacking.
fields.english_script: How confident are you in reducing your child’s risk for tooth decay?

fields.english_objective: Learn age appropriate methods for cleaning children’s teeth
fields.english_title: Tooth brushing- How many times a day are your child’s teeth brushed?
fields.english_script_instructions:
Parents should make tooth brushing appear as a fun activity; if the parent is enthusiastic about the activity, the children will be enthusiastic. Parents should make brushing seem like a fun thing to do rather than a chore. Kids like routine so parents should also set regular tooth brushing times and stick to them.  If possible, kids picking out their own toothbrush may help get them excited about it. 

For infants without teeth, gums should be wiped with a clean, damp cloth.  When teeth start to come in, parents should switch to a small soft toothbrush.  For children under 2- only a thin film of toothpaste should be used. For children over 2- a pea-sized amount of toothpaste should be used. Parents should supervise brushing until their child is 6-7 years old (Being able to tie own shoes and coloring within the lines are good markers.)  Most young children can hold and move a brush in their mouths BUT, they usually do a very poor job of brushing their teeth.  Brushing should be a family routine where the parent allows child to brush their teeth on their own with the parent “checking how they did” by brushing their teeth an additional time.
fields.english_script: Now we are going to talk about some of your child’s dental habits.  Does your child like having their teeth brushed? How many times a day are your child’s teeth brushed?

fields.english_objective: Learn that allowing a child to sleep with a bottle or sippy cup filled with a sugary drink (including milk) increases the child’s risk of early childhood caries.
fields.english_title: Bottle & Sippy Cup during the night
fields.english_script_instructions:
Parents may be anxious about taking the bottle away from their child if it helps them relax, sleep better, or stop crying.  Provide some suggestions on how to start a nighttime routine that does not include the bottle such as: sing or play music; hold or rock the baby; rub or pat the baby’s head or back; read or tell a story.  

If the baby already sleeps with a bottle, be sure he/she is fed before being put to bed.  Wipe teeth with a damp cloth after feeding. There are several techniques to try to wean a child from the bottle.  (1) Try giving a child the bottle in the living room with the family, then brush their teeth, go to their room and read, sing, and rock. This makes the baby not dependent on the bottle as a sleep crutch. (2) Try gradually diluting the liquid in the bottle with water until there is only water in the bottle.  (2) Also try to take it away slowly such as half an ounce out a day until it is gone then it can be taken away completely. (3) If the child is having multiple bottles per day, take one bottle away at a time. (4) If the baby is already a toddler and goes to bed with a bottle, explain that he/she is too big to have a bottle in bed anymore.

Children may have a hard time learning to sleep without it but eventually they will get the hang of it.  This may not be an easy or fast transition.  It may take days, weeks or even longer for the baby to give up the bottle in bed, but the mother needs to remain consistent in her actions.
fields.english_script: We just spoke about what your child drinks out of during the day.  Are they ever put to bed with a sippy cup or bottle with a sugary drink including milk?

fields.english_objective: Social Support
fields.english_title: Social Support- People in my neighborhood help each other out
fields.english_script: How much would you say you agree with the following statement?  People in my neighborhood help each other out.

fields.english_objective: Learn how to conduct a lift the lip exam on their child
fields.english_script: There is a simple way to check for early signs of early childhood caries by lifting your child’s lip and looking closely at their teeth.  The exam takes only a few seconds and can easily become a part of your child’s brushing routine.  Start by gently lifting your child’s upper lip and cheek. Look for plaque which is a sticky film of bacteria that sticks to teeth, the spaces between the teeth, and under gums. Does your child have any plaque on their upper four front teeth?

fields.english_objective: Initiate the food timeline
fields.english_title: Food timeline- when does your child wake up?
fields.english_script: We are going to go through a timeline and look at some pictures of foods and drinks.  To start the daily timeline, what time did your child wake up yesterday?

fields.english_objective: Initiate the food timeline
fields.english_title: Food timeline- when does your child go to sleep?
fields.english_script: What time did your child go to sleep?

fields.english_objective: Learn about how to reduce ad lib breast feeding during the night
fields.english_script: Are you breast feeding your child?  If so, how often do you breast feed ad lib during the night?

fields.english_objective: Learn the importance of flossing
fields.english_script: How many times a week are your child's teeth flossed?

fields.english_objective: Determine a typical eating day
fields.english_script: Now we are going to talk about what your child eats during the day.  Was yesterday a typical eating day for your child?

fields.english_objective: Learn the importance of where children eat
fields.english_script: Sometimes where our children eat influences how long it takes them to eat.  Where does your child typically eat their meals?

fields.english_objective: Learn the importance of where children eat
fields.english_script: Sometimes where our children eat influences how long it takes them to eat.  Where does your child typically eat their snacks?

fields.english_objective: Learn how food intake impacts caries risk
fields.english_script: Now let’s look at some pictures of foods and drinks.  What is the first thing that your child ate or drank yesterday?  What time did they eat or drink this item?  Would you consider this a meal or a snack?

fields.english_text: EN bullet
Teeth should be brushed at least twice a day, everyday.
Sharing utensils includes: Eating meals with the same utensils;   The mother testing the temperature or taste of the child’s food and then using the same utensil to feed the child.
If the child does not use a pacifier answer the question as never and move on to the next question.
You will continue to choose a slot on the time line and enter a food or drink from the series of pictures until you reach the end of the day.
Putting a child to bed with a bottle or sippy cup filled with a sugary drink (including milk and formula) should be avoided.
Someone other than the mother may include the grandparent, other parent, daycare teacher, or other caretaker.

The bacteria that cause cavities can be passed on from mother to child after a child’s baby teeth come in (at about 6-10 months).  This can be a serious problem if the mother herself has a lot of cavities, is not brushing her teeth well, or is not being treated by a dentist.
If the child does not use a pacifier answer the question as never and move on to the next question.
If the mother appears uncomfortable with this question, let them know that the practice of pre-chewing is common in some cultures.   A food mill or food processor is a safer way to soften foods.

This question is being used to examine social norms or a pattern of behavior in a particular group, community or culture.  A family's environment often influences their behavior.  We are asking about the habits of close friends and family members because their actions may influence this family's health behaviors.
If you find any white spots, discoloration or redness, contact the dentist.
If the parent answers sometimes, often, or always or appears anxious about taking the bottle away from their child. Refer to the further details below for suggestions.
Parents should check with their child’s dentist about their child’s specific fluoride needs
Prescription toothpaste usually contains a higher and stronger concentration of fluoride than regular toothpaste, in order to make up for these deficiencies.
Fluoride rinse should not be confused with breath freshening mouthwash

Sweets is referring to foods that help bacteria make more acid in the child’s mouth such as: soda and juice drinks;  Cookies, suckers, lollipops and hard candies, toffee taffy, caramel corn, gum drops, chocolate bars with rice cereal, nougat, candy-coated chocolate, candy corn; dried fruit, fruit roll-ups, chocolate-covered raisins, high energy candy bars or sport bars;  Sweetened cereals such as Fruit Loops, Corn Pops or Frosted Flakes
If the child eats in various places during the day, have the parent choose where they eat most often.
Parents may answer that their child drinks filtered water.  Most filtered tap water still contains fluoride.
If the parent has not brought their child to the dentist it is important to probe about barriers, if any.   The following bullets are some common barriers.
If the child eats in various places during the day, have the parent choose where they eat most often.
If the parent answers yes, then you will move into the assessment.  If no, you will ask them to provide the foods and drinks that their child eats in a typical day.
Flossing helps prevent cavities by removing plaque and food particles caught between teeth.
Breast feeding ad lib means feeding at will or as desired.
If you find any white spots, discoloration or redness, contact the dentist.

This question is being used to examine social support in a particular group, community or culture. A family's environment often influences their behavior.  We are asking about the support of close friends and family members because their actions may influence this family's health behaviors.
Parents may be concerned with using toothpaste with fluoride.  Assure them that when used correctly, fluoride toothpaste is safe and one of the best ways to prevent cavities in their children.

This question if referring to parents confidence at this time.  Are they confident in their ability (for example by improving their child's oral hygiene habits and improving their diet)  to reduce their child's risk for tooth decay.
If the parent is not regularly visiting the dentist it is important to probe about barriers, if any.
An abscessed tooth is a painful infection at the root of a tooth or between the gum and a tooth. Its most commonly caused by severe tooth decay and can also be referred to as a gum boil.

Cavities can be prevented:Not letting children sleep with baby bottles or sippy cups; Switching children to an infant cup by 12 months of age; Assisting children in tooth-brushing; “Lifting the lip” to check for white spots; Regular dental visits; Healthy diet with limited snacking.
Early Childhood Caries is a serious type of dental decay in young children that starts on the upper front teeth and can eventually attack the back teeth.

This question is being used to examine social norms or a pattern of behavior in a particular group, community or culture. A family's environment often influences their behavior.  We are asking about the habits of close friends and family members because their actions may influence this family's health behaviors.
Teeth should be brushed at least twice a day, everyday
If the exact item that the child ate/drank is not available in the list of categories, choose the most similar item.
Parents should avoid putting juice, soda, or other sweet drinks in a baby bottle.
Now would be a good time to watch the reducing sugared drinks video.
Parents should supervise brushing until their child is 6-7 years old (Being able to tie own shoes and coloring within the lines are good markers.)
Now may be a good time to watch the tooth brushing video
Children should being using toothpaste with fluoride when he/she turns 2 or earlier if the child is at high risk for dental caries.
Children under 6 years old should consult with a dentist before using fluoride rinse
No time
Other common names include baby bottle tooth decay, nursing bottle mouth or bottle rot
If the parent expresses difficulty in brushing their children’s teeth offer some suggestions from the additional details.
Sucking a pacifier is normal for infants and young children.
If the parent answers sometimes, often, or always or appears anxious about taking the bottle away from their child. Refer to the further details for suggestions.
Baby teeth help a child: Chew and enjoy food; Speak clearly;Guide and save space for adult teeth;Have a healthy smile that makes a child feel good about him/herself.

Common concerns for not visiting the dentist may include: No time; cost too much; have to travel too far; have to wait too long at the dentist's office; dentist doesn't speak their language; doesn't know of a dentist or clinic
Parents and caregivers play a very important role in finding and preventing ECC.

Ingesting too much fluoride can make a child ill and/or cause the permanent teeth to come in with white spots/discolorations on them.  Products containing fluoride should be stored out of the reach of young children.  Children should be encouraged to spit out the toothpaste.
Teeth should be brushed at least twice a day, everyday.
It’s important for the mother to understand that eliminating all contact with their child’s mouth is unrealistic.

The bacteria that cause cavities can be passed on from mother to child after a child’s baby teeth come in (at about 6-10 months) through pre chewing food. This can be a serious problem if the mother herself has a lot of cavities, is not brushing her teeth well, or is not being treated by a dentist.

Sharing utensils is one way that saliva and bacteria can be transferred from the mother to the child. The bacteria that cause cavities can be passed on from mother to child after a child’s baby teeth come in (at about 6-10 months).
Pacifiers should not be cleaned in a parent or caregiver’s mouth.  Run them under water, in a dishwater, or with a clean wipe.

Sweets is referring to foods that help bacteria make more acid in the child’s mouth such as: soda and juice drinks; Cookies, suckers, lollipops and hard candies, toffee taffy, caramel corn, gum drops, chocolate bars with rice cereal, nougat, candy-coated chocolate, candy corn; dried fruit, fruit roll-ups, chocolate-covered raisins, high energy candy bars or sport bars; Sweetened cereals such as Fruit Loops, Corn Pops or Frosted Flakes
Discovering and treating dental caries early (as a “white spot” vs. “a cavity”) is quicker, easier, cheaper and less stressful for both the parent and the child.
Discovering and treating dental caries early (as a “white spot” vs. “a cavity”) is quicker, easier, cheaper and less stressful for both the parent and the child.
Breast feeding is good for your baby but like a baby bottle, frequent and long feeding can put a child at risk for cavities.
Your child should be able to floss his or her own teeth by the time he or she is 9 years old. To floss younger children's teeth, place them in your lap facing you.
Don't think I need to because they have baby teeth which are going to fall out anyway
Parents forget or are misinformed about caring for their children’s baby teeth because they will fall out and are replaced with adult teeth.

Parents should dispense toothpaste to prevent their young children from swallowing too much. Use a smear of fluoridated toothpaste for children under 2 and a  pea-sized amount of toothpaste for children 2-5 years old.
Children should spit out and NOT swallow fluoride rinse.  Products with fluoride should be kept out of reach of young children.
If the parent expresses difficulty in brushing their children’s teeth offer some suggestions from the additional details.
Suggest speaking with their doctor for suggestions on how to relieve pain from teething.

The longer a parent is able to protect their child from receiving these bacteria and the less bacteria a mother has in her own mouth; the better a parent’s chances in decreasing their child’s risk for future cavities. A food mill or food processor is a safer way to soften foods.
Most young children can hold and move a brush in their mouths BUT, they usually do a very poor job of brushing their teeth.
It’s important for the mother to understand that eliminating all contact with their child’s mouth is unrealistic.
To reduce a child's risk for developing cavities, a mother who is breast feeding should finish nursing child and then put them to bed.
This can be a serious problem if the mother herself has a lot of cavities, is not brushing her teeth well, or is not being treated by a dentist.

The bacteria that cause cavities can be passed on from mother to child after a child’s baby teeth come in (at about 6-10 months). This can be a serious problem if the mother herself has a lot of cavities, is not brushing her teeth well, or is not being treated by a dentist.
Parents should avoid letting their baby carry bottle or sippy cut around throughout the day.
Now would be a good time to watch the reducing sugared drinks video.
Not taking care of a child’s baby teeth can cause cavities which can be painful, and can spread to other baby teeth and adult teeth.

Refer the parent to appropriate dental resources as needed.  Insurance and provider information can be found for children and pregnant women by contacting www.insurekidsnow.gov or 1-877-Kids-Now (1-877-543-7669).
Parents may not have access to tooth brushing and flossing tools.  It is important to assess this and refer the parent to the appropriate resource as needed.
Children should be weaned from the bottle to an infant cup by 12 to 14 months.
At your child’s regular check-ups, the dentist may recommend that a child receive a professional fluoride application.

Additional suggestions include using a clean finger (or cold teething ring) to gently rub the baby's gum for about 2 minutes at a time. Many babies find this soothing, although they may protest at first. Also, parents can provide safe objects for the baby to chew on, such as teething rings.
If the parent expresses difficulty in brushing their children’s teeth offer some suggestions from the additional details.

The longer a parent is able to protect their child from receiving these bacteria and the less bacteria a mother has in her own mouth; the better a parent’s chances in decreasing their child’s risk for future cavities.
It’s important for the mother to understand that eliminating all contact with their child’s mouth is unrealistic.
Child is afraid of dentist or pain
The baby teeth help the adult teeth to come in correctly and are very important for a child to be able to eat, speak, and feel good about him/herself.
A child will not lose all their baby teeth until they are about 11-12 years old.
Removing baby teeth early due to infection may also affect the future alignment of the permanent teeth.
Cost too much

The longer a parent is able to protect their child from receiving these bacteria and the less bacteria a mother has in her own mouth; the better a parent’s chances in decreasing their child’s risk for future cavities.
Unless being used at mealtime, the sippy cup should only be filled with water.
Afraid of being separated from the child
Have to travel too far
Have to wait too long at the office
Dentist doesn't speak my language
Don't know of any dentist or clinic
Afraid of child contracting a disease
Refer the parent to the appropriate dental resources as needed
Now may be a good time to have them watch the first dental visit video

fields.english_body: EN body

The sippy cup is a training tool to help children transition from a bottle to a cup.  It should not be used for a long period of time- it is not a bottle and not a pacifier. It should also not be used as a replacement for a bottle or pacifier.
Vertical Transmission is a term describing part of the disease process of dental caries where the bacteria responsible for dental caries is passed on from the parent (usually mother) to child.
Vertical Transmission is a term describing part of the disease process of dental caries where the bacteria responsible for dental caries is passed on from the parent (usually mother) to child.
Vertical Transmission is a term describing part of the disease process of dental caries where the bacteria responsible for dental caries is passed on from the parent (usually mother) to child.
Vertical Transmission is a term describing part of the disease process of dental caries where the bacteria responsible for dental caries is passed on from the parent (usually mother) to child.

The sippy cup is a training tool to help children transition from a bottle to a cup.  It should not be used for a long period of time- it is not a bottle and not a pacifier. It should also not be used as a replacement for a bottle or pacifier.
The state or practice of keeping the mouth cavity in a healthy condition, as by a regular program of brushing and flossing the teeth combined with periodic examinations by a dentist.

Fluoride is a mineral that helps protect the teeth from decay by hardening the tooth, repairing tiny areas of decay before they become big cavities, and making bacteria in plaque less able to cause decay.  Common sources include prescription-strength fluoride put on at the dentist’s office, toothpaste, and over-the-counter rinses that you can buy at the store.

Balanced diet means eating a wide variety of foods from all food groups, as well as eating everything in moderation.  Dairy products provide calcium and vitamin D for strengthening teeth and bones.  Breads and cereals supply B vitamins for growth and iron for healthy blood which adds to healthy gum tissue.  Fruits and vegetables containing Vitamin C (among other important vitamins) are essential to maintaining healthy gums.  Lean meat, poultry and beans provide iron and protein for overall health, and magnesium and zinc for teeth and bones.

Fluoride is a mineral that helps protect the teeth from decay by hardening the tooth, repairing tiny areas of decay before they become big cavities, and making bacteria in plaque less able to cause decay.  Common sources include prescription-strength fluoride put on at the dentist’s office, toothpaste, and over-the-counter rinses that you can buy at the store.
Dental Home: An accessible place where a child can receive consistent and comprehensive dental services, including dental restorations.

Lift the Lip exam is a simple and quick way to examine a child for early signs of Early Childhood Caries consisting of gently lifting a baby’s upper lip and cheek and looking for any discolorations on the teeth.
Early Childhood Caries is an aggressive and quickly progressing form of dental caries that affects children at a very young age.
Abscessed tooth is a painful infection at the root of a tooth or between the gum and a tooth that is most often caused by tooth decay.

Lift the Lip exam is a simple and quick way to examine a child for early signs of Early Childhood Caries consisting of gently lifting a baby’s upper lip and cheek and looking for any discolorations on the teeth.

Fluoride is a mineral that helps protect the teeth from decay by hardening the tooth, repairing tiny areas of decay before they become big cavities, and making bacteria in plaque less able to cause decay.  Common sources include prescription-strength fluoride put on at the dentist’s office, toothpaste, and over-the-counter rinses that you can buy at the store.
Prescription toothpaste usually contains a higher and stronger concentration of fluoride than regular toothpaste, in order to make up for these deficiencies.
Enamel Fluorosis is a condition that occurs when inappropriate levels of fluoride are ingested by a child during specific time of tooth development, causing discolorations on the permanent teeth
White Spot is a term to describe the early stages of tooth decay.
Enamel Fluorosis is a condition that occurs when inappropriate levels of fluoride are ingested by a child during specific time of tooth development, causing discolorations on the permanent teeth

Pediatric dentistry is the specialty of dentistry that focuses on the oral health of young people. After completing a four-year dental school curriculum, two to three additional years of rigorous training are required to become a pediatric dentist. This specialized program of study and hands-on experience prepares pediatric dentists to meet the needs of infants, children and adolescents, including persons with special health care needs.

Fluoride is a mineral that helps protect the teeth from decay by hardening the tooth, repairing tiny areas of decay before they become big cavities, and making bacteria in plaque less able to cause decay.  Common sources include prescription-strength fluoride put on at the dentist’s office, toothpaste, and over-the-counter rinses that you can buy at the store.
A small quantity of a liquid taken into the mouth and swallowed
